title: Sleep and Cardiovascular Disease
content: Sleep and cardiovascular disease. Why is CVD worsened (or accelerated) by sleep deprivation? With lack of sleep, the body becomes much more driven by the sympathetic nervous system. This means more adrenaline release, high spike in cortisol levels,  and blunting of growth hormone (all factors leading to atherosclerosis). Lack of sleep increases blood pressure (hypertension).

title: Fuel Partitioning and Dieting While Sleep Deprived
content: Fuel partitioning and dieting while sleep deprived. Dietary changes when you are sleep deprived: Inferior fuel partitioning, Hyperinsulinemia, Impaired glucose disposal, A tendency to probably eat more crap.

title: Sleep and the Reproductive Function
content: Sleep and the reproductive function: testosterone, sperm count, FSH, menstrual cycles, and fertility. Men who only get 5-6 hrs sleep have testosterone levels of men 10 years older. Men who sleep 5 hrs a night have smaller testicles. Men who sleep 6 hrs or less have fewer sperm and their sperm have more deformities in the sperm. Women who sleep 5-6 hrs have a 20% reduction in FSH (a critical part of the reproductive pathway). They also have a 30% higher rate of abnormal menstrual cycles.

title: The Biological Necessity of Sleep
content: The biological necessity of sleep, the lack of a safety net, sleep debt, and ways to course correct sleep problems. Human beings are the only species that deliberately deprive themselves of sleep for no apparent reason.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Health
content: Under conditions of starvation, animals need to be more alert to search for food. However, this feeling is temporary and sleep debt still accumulates. Mother Nature has never had to face challenge of sleep deprivation, so no biological safety nets exist for any essential functions without sleep. People often think they can accumulate sleep debt during the week and then make it up on the weekend, but this is like sleep bulimia and is torture on circadian biology. There is a whole arsenal of tools in the sleep doc kind of box that we can use, to sort of make these manipulations, either be it for people with insomnia, be it people with anxiety, be it people with jet lag, or what’s called circadian phase delay.

title: Sleep and Immune Function
content: Significant link exists between sleep and cancer of bowel, prostate, and breast. Causal evidence is so strong that WHO has classified night shift work as a probable carcinogen. Partial sleep deprivation reduces natural killer cell activity in humans. One night of poor sleep caused 70% drop in natural killer cell activity. Sleep gets worse as we age, and therefore our immune system gets worse. Sleep is probably one of the most powerful regulators of your immune system.

title: Sleep and Cancer Development
content: Study using mice showed that underslept mice had tumors 200% larger than mice who slept normally. Cancer in underslept mice had also metastasized. The mechanism is that Macrophage M1 cells are downregulated, and M2 cells (which promote tumor growth) are upregulated by lack of sleep.

title: Medical Profession and Sleep Deprivation
content: Most medical students get 1-2 hours of instruction about sleep during medical school. This is despite the fact that sleep takes up 1/3 of your life and makes such a huge difference to the 2/3 of life spent awake. Medicine is a culture that devalues sleep. If attending surgeon has slept only 6 hrs of previous 24, there is 170% greater chance of major surgical error. If resident works 30 hour shift vs. 16 hour shift, there is 178% increased likelihood of car crash.

title: Sleep Needs of Children
content: School starts way too early which is impacting the sleep of children. When you delay school start times, grades improve and attendance improves, behavior problems drop, and life expectancy goes up due to reduced car crashes. Teens need to go to bed later and sleep later. They need 9-10 hrs sleep even when 16-18 years old. On average, teens get about 7 hrs of sleep which is a bigger relative deficit than in adults.

title: Impact of School Start Times on Health
content: When school start times are delayed, SAT scores and grades in morning classes improve significantly. A 10am start time is suggested as the sweet spot. The school day doesn't need to be as long if students could learn more efficiently. There is also a possible reduction in criminal behavior as much of it happens between 3-4pm when kids are out of school and parents aren’t yet home from work.

title: Effects of Technology on Sleep
content: Excessive technology use and exposure to light can negatively impact sleep. We are 'dark deprived' and need darkness to release melatonin. Using an iPad before bed can cause a 50% drop in melatonin, delay the peak melatonin arrival by 3 hours, reduce REM time, and these effects can last 2-3 days. Television usage can make the brain associate the bedroom with TV, which can trigger insomnia and anxiety. Devices can cause sleep procrastination and anticipatory anxiety, which can reduce the amount of deep sleep.

title: Recommendations for Better Sleep
content: To get better sleep, limit technology use, especially in the bedroom. Social media in the bedroom can lead to fear of missing out, which can lead to insufficient sleep. If you struggle with sleep, you should read in a different room and go to bed when sleepy. LED light bulbs are more deleterious in terms of suppressing melatonin. Warm red and yellow light is best, though all light will interfere with melatonin. Lower wattage light is best for reading at night.

title: Effects of Light Exposure on Sleep
content: Experiments have shown that infants in an environment with fluorescent lights on all the time need signals of light and dark. When it was made dark at night, babies had 50% better oxygen saturation, put on more weight, and left the NICU 2-2.5 weeks earlier. Modern society has changed our sleep habits by reducing the amount of sleep, changing the timing of sleep, and changing the nature in which we obtain our sleep.

title: Efficacy of Naps
content: Experiments show naps benefit learning, memory, immune function, cardiovascular health and lower systolic blood pressure. 20 minute naps can still see some mental benefits, in terms of things like learning and memory. 90 minute naps give the brain the ability to go through all the stages of non-REM sleep. However, if you have trouble sleeping at night, you should not nap during the day.

title: Effect of Cortisol Levels on Sleep
content: Sleep is a balance among adenosine, cortisol, and melatonin. High cortisol levels can cause insomnia. The leading theory of insomnia is that the flight or fight/parasympathetic state of the nervous system is 'turned up' too far. In cases of insomnia, cortisol is down in the evening but then right before bed it spikes again, sometimes spikes again in the middle of the night and keeping someone from falling back asleep.

title: Harmful Effects of Sleeping Pills
content: Sleeping pills on the market now, such as Ambien and Lunesta, do not produce naturalistic sleep and are associated with a higher risk of death and cancer. Ambien is more like a 'chemical baseball bat to the head' than something that’s actually promoting restorative and restful sleep.

title: Sedative-hypnotics and Sleep Quality
content: Current sleep drugs like Ambien and Lunesta are sedative-hypnotics. Sedation is not sleep, it’s knocking your cortex out. Not awake but also not in naturalistic sleep. Not same quality of deep sleep. Higher association with mortality risk and linked to cancer.

title: Study on Brain Plasticity
content: Strengthening of brain connections leads to formation of memories. The brain can adapt and rewire itself. If cover one eye, brain “rewires” connections to other eye’s section of brain (a phenomenon known as monocular deprivation plasticity).

title: Effects of Sedative-hypnotics on Brain Plasticity
content: The study took a group of animal and put an eye patch on them. First he allowed them “naturalistic” sleep. Sleep “basically doubles strengthening of plasticity” relative to if you just keep the animal awake. Then he dosed animals with Ambien. They slept longer, so would guess it would improve rewiring, but made it worse. Led to 50% unwiring of connections that had been laid down before.

title: Concerns about Sedative-hypnotics and Developing Brains
content: As parents get more concerned about their kids who may have more anxiety, who are having sleep problems, they’re turning to pills. You’ve got a brain that is developing, a brain that need to wire itself up, strengthen connections, build and mature, it needs to learn, it needs to consolidate, and then you’re providing a form of sleep through medication that may actually be un-wiring that nervous system, and un-wiring those memories, rather than strengthening them.
